_link.title: I can explain why forces perpendicular to displacement do no work

toLevel2.question: What is the value of cos 90°?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Cos 90° = 0, which is why a force perpendicular to displacement produces zero work.

distractors.explanation: Cos 0° = 1, not cos 90°. This applies when force and displacement are aligned.
Cos 180° = −1, not cos 90°. This applies when force opposes displacement.
Cos 60° = 0.5, not cos 90°. The cosine of 90° is exactly zero.

toLevel2.question: When a force acts perpendicular to the direction of motion, how much work does it do?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: W = Fs cos 90° = 0. A perpendicular force has no component in the direction of displacement.

distractors.answer: Maximum work
distractors.explanation: Maximum work occurs when force is parallel to displacement (θ = 0°), not perpendicular.

distractors.answer: Negative work
distractors.explanation: Negative work requires force opposing displacement (90° < θ < 180°), not perpendicular.

distractors.answer: Half the maximum work
distractors.explanation: Half occurs at θ = 60° (cos 60° = 0.5), not at θ = 90°.

toLevel2.question: In uniform circular motion, which force acts on the object?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The centripetal force always points toward the centre of the circular path, perpendicular to the velocity.

distractors.answer: A force in the direction of motion
distractors.explanation: In uniform circular motion there is no net force along the direction of motion; the force is radial.

distractors.answer: No force acts on the object at all
distractors.explanation: A net force must act to change the direction of velocity; this is the centripetal force.

distractors.answer: A centrifugal force outward from centre
distractors.explanation: Centrifugal force is a fictitious force in rotating frames; the real force is centripetal, directed inward.

toLevel2.question: Why does the kinetic energy of an object in uniform circular motion remain constant?
toLevel2.correct: The centripetal force is perpendicular to velocity
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Since the force is always perpendicular to displacement, no work is done and kinetic energy stays constant.

distractors.answer: There is no force acting on the object
distractors.explanation: A centripetal force acts continuously, but it does no work because it is perpendicular to motion.

distractors.answer: The speed increases and decreases equally
distractors.explanation: In uniform circular motion, speed is genuinely constant, not fluctuating.

distractors.answer: Energy is continuously supplied to the object
distractors.explanation: No energy input is needed to maintain uniform circular motion in the absence of friction.

toLevel2.question: A waiter carries a tray of food horizontally across a room. Does the waiter do work against gravity on the tray?
toLevel2.correct: No, because the motion is perpendicular to gravity
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Gravity acts downward while displacement is horizontal, making θ = 90° and work = 0.

distractors.answer: Yes, because the waiter exerts an upward force
distractors.explanation: The upward support force balances gravity but causes no vertical displacement, so no work is done.

distractors.answer: Yes, because the tray has weight and is moving
distractors.explanation: Having weight and moving does not guarantee work; the force must have a component along displacement.

distractors.answer: It depends on the speed of the waiter
distractors.explanation: Speed does not affect whether work is done; what matters is the angle between force and displacement.

toLevel2.question: An object in uniform circular motion has constant kinetic energy because no work is done on it by the centripetal force.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The centripetal force is always perpendicular to velocity, so W = Fs cos 90° = 0 and kinetic energy stays constant.

distractors.answer: False
distractors.explanation: Students may think a force must change energy, but perpendicular forces change direction without changing speed or energy.

toLevel2.question: A force can act on an object without doing any work on it.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: When force is perpendicular to displacement, work is zero even though a force is present.

distractors.answer: False
distractors.explanation: Students may assume all forces do work, but perpendicular forces transfer no energy.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the sentence about perpendicular forces.
toLevel2.sentence: When a force is perpendicular to displacement, the work done is {{blank:1}} because cos 90° equals {{blank:2}}.

1.correctExplanation: W = Fs cos 90° = Fs × 0 = 0, so no energy is transferred.

distractors.answer: maximum
distractors.explanation: Maximum work occurs at θ = 0°, not 90°.

distractors.answer: negative
distractors.explanation: Negative work requires θ between 90° and 180°, not exactly 90°.

2.correctExplanation: The cosine of 90° is exactly zero, which makes the entire work calculation zero.

distractors.answer: one
distractors.explanation: Cos 0° = 1, not cos 90°.

distractors.answer: negative one
distractors.explanation: Cos 180° = −1, not cos 90°.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the sentence about circular motion.
toLevel2.sentence: In uniform circular motion, the centripetal force is always {{blank:1}} to the velocity of the object.

1.correctExplanation: The centripetal force points toward the centre while velocity is tangent to the circle, making them perpendicular.

distractors.answer: parallel
distractors.explanation: If the force were parallel to velocity, the object would speed up or slow down, not travel in a circle.

distractors.answer: opposite
distractors.explanation: An opposing force would decelerate the object along its path, not cause circular motion.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the sentence about force components.
toLevel2.sentence: Only the component of force that is {{blank:1}} to displacement can do work on an object.

1.correctExplanation: The parallel component (F cos θ) is the only part that transfers energy to or from the object.

distractors.answer: perpendicular
distractors.explanation: The perpendicular component changes direction but does not transfer energy.

distractors.answer: equal
distractors.explanation: The force does not need to equal the displacement; it needs a component along the displacement direction.

toLevel3.question: Why does the gravitational force do no work on a satellite in a circular orbit?
toLevel3.correct: Gravity is always perpendicular to the satellite's displacement
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The gravitational force points radially inward while the satellite moves tangentially, so the angle between them is always 90°.

distractors.answer: Gravity is too weak in space to do any work
distractors.explanation: Gravity is not weak; it provides the centripetal force. It does no work because of its perpendicular direction.

distractors.answer: The satellite has no mass in orbit
distractors.explanation: The satellite retains its mass in orbit; the zero work is due to the force-displacement angle.

distractors.answer: The satellite is moving too fast for gravity to act
distractors.explanation: Gravity acts continuously on the satellite regardless of speed; it does no work because of geometry.

toLevel3.question: A ball on a string is swung in a horizontal circle at constant speed. What work does the tension in the string do?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The tension always points toward the centre while the ball moves tangentially, so force is perpendicular to displacement.

distractors.answer: Positive work equal to the kinetic energy
distractors.explanation: The tension maintains the circle but does not increase the ball's energy.

distractors.answer: Negative work that slows the ball
distractors.explanation: The ball maintains constant speed because tension does no work.

distractors.answer: Work equal to tension multiplied by circumference
distractors.explanation: This incorrectly assumes the force is parallel to the circular path.

toLevel3.question: A person carries a heavy box across a level floor. How much work does the person do against gravity?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The upward support force and displacement are perpendicular (force vertical, displacement horizontal), so no work is done against gravity.

distractors.answer: Equal to the weight times the distance walked
distractors.explanation: This would be true if the person lifted the box vertically, but horizontal motion is perpendicular to gravity.

distractors.answer: Equal to the kinetic energy of the box
distractors.explanation: The kinetic energy relates to horizontal force, not the vertical gravitational force.

distractors.answer: Equal to half the weight times the distance
distractors.explanation: No fraction of the weight does work when displacement is entirely perpendicular to gravity.

toLevel3.question: What physical quantity changes when a centripetal force acts on an object in circular motion?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The centripetal force changes the direction of the velocity vector without changing its magnitude (speed).

distractors.answer: The speed of the object
distractors.explanation: In uniform circular motion, speed remains constant because the force is perpendicular to velocity.

distractors.answer: The kinetic energy of the object
distractors.explanation: Kinetic energy depends on speed, which does not change in uniform circular motion.

distractors.answer: The mass of the object in motion
distractors.explanation: Mass does not change due to forces acting on the object.

toLevel3.question: A charged particle moves through a magnetic field. The magnetic force is always perpendicular to the particle's velocity. What effect does this have?
toLevel3.correct: The particle changes direction but maintains constant speed
toLevel3.correctExplanation: A perpendicular force does no work, so kinetic energy and speed are unchanged, but direction changes.

distractors.answer: The particle accelerates and gains kinetic energy
distractors.explanation: The perpendicular force cannot increase kinetic energy; it only changes direction.

distractors.answer: The particle slows down and eventually stops
distractors.explanation: The force does no work, so the particle cannot lose kinetic energy to the magnetic force.

distractors.answer: The particle moves in a straight line at higher speed
distractors.explanation: A perpendicular force curves the path rather than keeping it straight.

toLevel3.question: An object moves in a straight line while a force acts perpendicular to its motion. What happens to its speed?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: A perpendicular force does zero work, so it cannot change the kinetic energy or speed of the object.

distractors.answer: Its speed increases gradually
distractors.explanation: A perpendicular force has no component along the motion and cannot increase speed.

distractors.answer: Its speed decreases gradually
distractors.explanation: The force does no work and cannot remove kinetic energy from the object.

distractors.answer: Its speed fluctuates randomly
distractors.explanation: The effect is predictable: zero work means constant kinetic energy and constant speed.

toLevel3.question: The normal force on a book sliding across a horizontal table does zero work on the book.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The normal force acts vertically upward while the book moves horizontally, so force is perpendicular to displacement.

distractors.answer: False
distractors.explanation: Students may think the normal force contributes to the motion, but it is perpendicular to the horizontal displacement.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the sentence about work and direction.
toLevel3.sentence: A force perpendicular to displacement changes the {{blank:1}} of an object's velocity without changing its {{blank:2}}.

1.correctExplanation: A perpendicular force deflects the object, changing its velocity direction.

distractors.answer: magnitude
distractors.explanation: The magnitude of velocity (speed) is unchanged by a perpendicular force.

distractors.answer: mass
distractors.explanation: Mass is not affected by applied forces.

2.correctExplanation: Since no work is done, kinetic energy and speed remain constant.

distractors.answer: direction
distractors.explanation: Direction is exactly what changes when a perpendicular force acts.

distractors.answer: position
distractors.explanation: Position changes as the object moves; speed is what remains constant.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the sentence about the normal force.
toLevel3.sentence: The normal force on an object sliding across a horizontal surface does {{blank:1}} work because it acts {{blank:2}} to the displacement.

1.correctExplanation: The normal force is vertical while displacement is horizontal, giving W = Fs cos 90° = 0.

distractors.answer: positive
distractors.explanation: The normal force does not accelerate the object horizontally and does no work.

distractors.answer: negative
distractors.explanation: Negative work requires a force component opposing displacement, which the normal force does not have.

2.correctExplanation: The normal force is vertical and displacement is horizontal, making them perpendicular.

distractors.answer: parallel
distractors.explanation: Parallel would mean the force acts in the direction of motion, which the normal force does not.

distractors.answer: opposite
distractors.explanation: Opposite would mean the force opposes motion; the normal force acts vertically, not horizontally.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the sentence about circular motion energy.
toLevel3.sentence: In uniform circular motion, the kinetic energy remains {{blank:1}} because the centripetal force does no work.

1.correctExplanation: No work means no energy transfer, so kinetic energy does not change.

distractors.answer: increasing
distractors.explanation: Kinetic energy would increase only if positive work were done on the object.

distractors.answer: decreasing
distractors.explanation: Kinetic energy would decrease only if negative work were done on the object.

toLevel4.question: A car travels at constant speed around a banked curve. The normal force from the road has both vertical and horizontal components. Which component does work on the car?
toLevel4.correct: Neither component does work if speed is constant
toLevel4.correctExplanation: At constant speed on a banked curve, the net force is centripetal (perpendicular to velocity), so no work is done and kinetic energy is unchanged.

distractors.answer: The horizontal component does positive work
distractors.explanation: The horizontal component provides centripetal force, which is perpendicular to the car's velocity.

distractors.answer: The vertical component does negative work
distractors.explanation: The vertical component balances gravity with no vertical displacement, so it does no work.

distractors.answer: Both components do equal amounts of work
distractors.explanation: Neither component does work when the car maintains constant speed around the curve.

toLevel4.question: A satellite moves from point A to point B in its circular orbit. An engineer claims the gravitational force does work equal to mgh, where h is the altitude. Why is this incorrect?
toLevel4.correct: The displacement is tangential, not radial, so gravity does no work
toLevel4.correctExplanation: In a circular orbit, displacement is always perpendicular to the radial gravitational force, giving zero work at every point.

distractors.answer: The altitude does not change in a circular orbit
distractors.explanation: While altitude is constant, the key reason is that force and displacement are perpendicular.

distractors.answer: Gravity does not act in space beyond the atmosphere
distractors.explanation: Gravity acts on satellites; it provides the centripetal force for the orbit.

distractors.answer: Work should be calculated as mgh/2 in orbit
distractors.explanation: No fraction of mgh applies because the force is perpendicular to displacement, giving zero work.

toLevel4.question: A pendulum swings from its highest point to the lowest point. At the lowest point, does the tension in the string do work on the bob?
toLevel4.correct: No, because tension is perpendicular to the bob's velocity
toLevel4.correctExplanation: At every point in the swing, the tension acts along the string toward the pivot, perpendicular to the tangential velocity of the bob.

distractors.answer: Yes, tension does positive work accelerating the bob
distractors.explanation: The bob accelerates due to the tangential component of gravity, not tension. Tension is always perpendicular to velocity.

distractors.answer: Yes, tension does negative work slowing the bob
distractors.explanation: Tension is perpendicular to the path and cannot slow the bob; only gravity's tangential component does that.

distractors.answer: Tension does work only at the highest point
distractors.explanation: At all points of the swing, tension is perpendicular to velocity and does zero work.

toLevel4.question: A frictionless roller coaster car goes around a vertical loop. At the top of the loop, the normal force from the track points downward toward the centre. Does this normal force do work?
toLevel4.correct: No, because it is perpendicular to the car's velocity
toLevel4.correctExplanation: At the top of the loop, the car moves horizontally while the normal force points vertically downward, making them perpendicular.

distractors.answer: Yes, it does positive work by pushing the car forward
distractors.explanation: The normal force points toward the centre of the loop, not along the direction of motion.

distractors.answer: Yes, it does negative work by opposing the car's motion
distractors.explanation: The normal force is centripetal and perpendicular to velocity, not opposing it.

distractors.answer: It does work equal to the car's gravitational potential energy
distractors.explanation: The normal force at any point in circular motion is perpendicular to velocity and does zero work.

toLevel4.question: An ice skater glides in a straight line across frictionless ice. Gravity and the normal force act on the skater. What is the total work done by these two forces?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Both gravity (downward) and normal force (upward) are perpendicular to the horizontal displacement, so neither does any work.

distractors.answer: Equal to the skater's kinetic energy
distractors.explanation: The skater's kinetic energy remains constant; these perpendicular forces do no work.

distractors.answer: Equal to mg times the distance travelled
distractors.explanation: This would apply if the skater moved vertically, but the displacement is horizontal and perpendicular to both forces.

distractors.answer: Negative, because gravity pulls the skater down
distractors.explanation: Gravity acts vertically but displacement is horizontal, so no work is done.

toLevel4.question: A planet orbits a star in a perfectly circular orbit. Over one complete orbit, what is the net work done by gravity?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: At every point in a circular orbit, gravity is perpendicular to the planet's velocity, so the instantaneous work is always zero.

distractors.answer: Equal to the orbital kinetic energy
distractors.explanation: Kinetic energy remains constant throughout a circular orbit because gravity does no work.

distractors.answer: Equal to 2πr times the gravitational force
distractors.explanation: This assumes force is parallel to displacement around the orbit, but they are perpendicular.

distractors.answer: Positive during half the orbit, negative during the other half
distractors.explanation: This describes elliptical orbits, not circular orbits where force and velocity are always perpendicular.

toLevel4.question: A bucket of water is swung in a vertical circle at constant speed. At the side of the circle (3 o'clock position), what is the direction of the net force?
toLevel4.correct: Horizontally toward the centre of the circle
toLevel4.correctExplanation: At the 3 o'clock position, the centripetal acceleration points horizontally toward the centre, perpendicular to the upward or downward velocity.

distractors.answer: Vertically downward due to gravity only
distractors.explanation: Gravity acts downward, but tension also acts, and the net force must point toward the centre for circular motion.

distractors.answer: Tangent to the circle in the direction of motion
distractors.explanation: At constant speed, there is no tangential net force; the net force is centripetal.

distractors.answer: Vertically upward opposing gravity on the bucket
distractors.explanation: The net force must point toward the centre of the circle, not simply upward.

toLevel4.prompt: Complete the sentence about the pendulum.
toLevel4.sentence: The tension in a pendulum string does no work on the bob because tension is always {{blank:1}} to the bob's velocity along the arc.

1.correctExplanation: Tension acts along the string toward the pivot, which is always at 90° to the tangential velocity.

distractors.answer: parallel
distractors.explanation: If tension were parallel to velocity, it would do work and change the bob's speed directly.

distractors.answer: opposite
distractors.explanation: Tension points toward the pivot, not opposite to the direction of swing.

toLevel4.prompt: Complete the sentence about forces in orbit.
toLevel4.sentence: A satellite in circular orbit maintains constant speed because the gravitational force is {{blank:1}} to the direction of {{blank:2}}.

1.correctExplanation: Gravity points radially inward while the satellite moves tangentially, making them perpendicular.

distractors.answer: parallel
distractors.explanation: Gravity is radial and velocity is tangential; they are perpendicular in circular orbit.

distractors.answer: opposite
distractors.explanation: Gravity does not act opposite to the satellite's velocity in circular orbit.

2.correctExplanation: The satellite's direction of motion is tangent to the orbit, perpendicular to the radial gravitational force.

distractors.answer: gravity
distractors.explanation: This would make the sentence say gravity is perpendicular to gravity, which is circular.

distractors.answer: acceleration
distractors.explanation: The acceleration is centripetal and parallel to gravity, not perpendicular to it.

toLevel4.prompt: Complete the sentence about the normal force.
toLevel4.sentence: On a flat surface, the normal force never does work because there is no {{blank:1}} displacement.

1.correctExplanation: The normal force is vertical, so it requires vertical displacement to do work, which does not occur on a flat surface.

distractors.answer: horizontal
distractors.explanation: There is horizontal displacement on a flat surface; the normal force is vertical and perpendicular to it.

distractors.answer: angular
distractors.explanation: Angular displacement is relevant to rotational motion, not the linear work done by the normal force.

toLevel5.question: A spacecraft uses a gravitational slingshot around a planet in a hyperbolic trajectory. Unlike circular orbits, the spacecraft gains speed. How does this relate to the perpendicular force principle?
toLevel5.correct: The trajectory is not circular, so gravity is not always perpendicular to velocity
toLevel5.correctExplanation: In a non-circular trajectory, gravity has a component along the velocity direction at most points, allowing it to do work and change speed.

distractors.answer: Gravity becomes stronger near the planet and does more work
distractors.explanation: While gravity is stronger closer, the key is that the force is no longer perpendicular to velocity in non-circular paths.

distractors.answer: The planet's motion adds energy that violates the perpendicular rule
distractors.explanation: The planet's motion does transfer energy, but the fundamental point is that force is not perpendicular in a slingshot.

distractors.answer: The perpendicular force principle does not apply in space
distractors.explanation: The principle applies everywhere; it is the trajectory shape that determines whether the force is perpendicular.

toLevel5.question: A conical pendulum swings in a horizontal circle at constant speed. The string tension has both vertical and horizontal components. Which component does work?
toLevel5.correct: Neither component does work on the bob
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The vertical component balances gravity with no vertical displacement, and the horizontal component provides centripetal force perpendicular to the horizontal velocity.

distractors.answer: The horizontal component does positive work
distractors.explanation: The horizontal component is centripetal, pointing toward the centre and perpendicular to the tangential velocity.

distractors.answer: The vertical component does negative work
distractors.explanation: The vertical component supports the bob against gravity, but there is no vertical displacement.

distractors.answer: Both components do work that cancels out
distractors.explanation: Neither component does any work; this is not a case of cancellation.

toLevel5.question: An electron spirals in a magnetic field. The magnetic force is always perpendicular to velocity. If the electron also passes through an electric field parallel to its velocity, what changes?
toLevel5.correct: The electric field does work, changing the electron's speed
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The electric force parallel to velocity has a component along displacement and therefore does work, unlike the perpendicular magnetic force.

distractors.answer: Both fields now do work on the electron equally
distractors.explanation: The magnetic force remains perpendicular to velocity and still does no work regardless of the electric field.

distractors.answer: The electric field also does no work on the electron
distractors.explanation: A force parallel to velocity is not perpendicular and therefore does do work.

distractors.answer: The magnetic force starts doing work due to the electric field
distractors.explanation: The magnetic force is always perpendicular to velocity by definition and never does work.

toLevel5.question: A cyclist rides at constant speed around a velodrome (banked circular track). Ignoring air resistance and friction losses, what work does the normal force from the banked surface do?
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The normal force is perpendicular to the track surface and to the cyclist's velocity. At constant speed, no net work is done.

distractors.answer: Positive work equal to the centripetal energy
distractors.explanation: There is no concept of centripetal energy; the centripetal force is perpendicular to velocity and does no work.

distractors.answer: Negative work opposing the cyclist's motion
distractors.explanation: The normal force is perpendicular to velocity and does not oppose or assist the motion.

distractors.answer: Work equal to mgs where s is the distance
distractors.explanation: This formula applies when force is parallel to displacement; the normal force is perpendicular.

toLevel5.question: A Ferris wheel rotates at constant angular speed. At the top, gravity points downward and the passenger moves horizontally. At the side, the passenger moves vertically. Over one full revolution, what net work does gravity do?
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Over a complete revolution, the passenger returns to the same height, so the net vertical displacement is zero and gravity does zero net work.

distractors.answer: Positive, because gravity accelerates the passenger on the way down
distractors.explanation: While gravity does positive work on the descent, it does equal negative work on the ascent, giving zero net work over a full revolution.

distractors.answer: Negative, because the motor must fight gravity
distractors.explanation: The motor does work, but gravity itself does zero net work over a complete revolution.

distractors.answer: Equal to mg times the circumference of the wheel
distractors.explanation: This treats gravity as if it were always parallel to displacement, but the angle varies continuously.

toLevel5.question: A hammer thrower spins a 7.26 kg hammer in a horizontal circle, gradually increasing its speed before release. During the acceleration phase, is the centripetal force the only force acting horizontally?
toLevel5.correct: No, a tangential force must also act to increase the speed
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The centripetal force is perpendicular to velocity and cannot change speed. A tangential force component parallel to velocity must do work to increase kinetic energy.

distractors.answer: Yes, the centripetal force increases speed and direction
distractors.explanation: The centripetal force can only change direction; it cannot increase speed because it is perpendicular to velocity.

distractors.answer: Yes, but the centripetal force changes to become tangential
distractors.explanation: The centripetal force always points toward the centre; a separate tangential force must act.

distractors.answer: No force is needed because the hammer naturally speeds up
distractors.explanation: Speed increases only when a net force component acts along the direction of motion.

toLevel5.question: In a particle accelerator, charged particles travel in circular paths using magnetic fields. Why are electric fields, not magnetic fields, used to accelerate the particles?
toLevel5.correct: Magnetic forces are perpendicular to velocity and cannot do work
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The magnetic force is always perpendicular to the particle's velocity, so it changes direction but cannot increase kinetic energy. Electric fields can act parallel to velocity.

distractors.answer: Magnetic fields are too weak to accelerate particles
distractors.explanation: Magnetic fields can be very strong; the issue is direction, not magnitude.

distractors.answer: Electric fields are perpendicular while magnetic fields are parallel
distractors.explanation: This reverses the actual situation; magnetic force is always perpendicular to velocity.

distractors.answer: Both can accelerate particles equally but electric fields are cheaper
distractors.explanation: The distinction is physical, not economic; magnetic forces fundamentally cannot do work.

toLevel5.question: An amusement park ride spins passengers in a vertical circle. At what position(s) does gravity do zero instantaneous work on a passenger?
toLevel5.correct: At the very top and very bottom of the circle
toLevel5.correctExplanation: At the top and bottom, velocity is horizontal while gravity is vertical, making them perpendicular and giving zero instantaneous work.

distractors.answer: At the sides of the circle (3 and 9 o'clock positions)
distractors.explanation: At the sides, velocity has a vertical component parallel to gravity, so gravity does non-zero work.

distractors.answer: Gravity does zero work at all positions in the circle
distractors.explanation: This is only true for a horizontal circle; in a vertical circle, gravity does work at most positions.

distractors.answer: Gravity never does zero work during the rotation
distractors.explanation: At the top and bottom, gravity is perpendicular to the horizontal velocity, giving zero work at those instants.

toLevel5.prompt: Complete the analysis of forces and work in circular motion.
toLevel5.sentence: To increase the speed of an object in circular motion, a force component {{blank:1}} to the velocity must act, because the centripetal force is {{blank:2}} to velocity and cannot change speed.

1.correctExplanation: A parallel force component does positive work, increasing kinetic energy and speed.

distractors.answer: perpendicular
distractors.explanation: A perpendicular force changes direction only and cannot increase speed.

distractors.answer: equal
distractors.explanation: The force need not equal the velocity; it must have a component along the velocity direction.

2.correctExplanation: The centripetal force always points toward the centre, perpendicular to the tangential velocity.

distractors.answer: parallel
distractors.explanation: If centripetal force were parallel to velocity, it would change speed rather than direction.

distractors.answer: opposite
distractors.explanation: The centripetal force is inward and perpendicular, not opposite to the direction of motion.

toLevel5.prompt: Complete the sentence about magnetic force and work.
toLevel5.sentence: In a particle accelerator, {{blank:1}} fields steer particles in circles while {{blank:2}} fields accelerate them, because only forces with a component along velocity can do work.

1.correctExplanation: Magnetic forces are always perpendicular to velocity, so they change direction without changing speed.

distractors.answer: electric
distractors.explanation: Electric fields can act parallel to velocity and are used for acceleration, not steering.

distractors.answer: gravitational
distractors.explanation: Gravitational fields are negligible for charged particle control in accelerators.

2.correctExplanation: Electric fields can exert force parallel to velocity, doing work and increasing kinetic energy.

distractors.answer: magnetic
distractors.explanation: Magnetic forces are perpendicular to velocity and cannot accelerate particles.

distractors.answer: nuclear
distractors.explanation: Nuclear forces act at subatomic distances and are not used for bulk particle acceleration.
